Actually after making a new virtual-env to test; my jdbc connections no longer appear in the adhoc query selector so it appears i've missed something. Although I'm not sure what. *edit was running airflow from the wrong virtual env... anyways screen shots below. Note: after the change Teradata still won't run because of the way airflow currently limits sql. It has a generic else clause that uses limit which Teradata doesn't support. A quick glance of the [code](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/www/utils.py#L65) looks like it uses the connection type to edit the limit clause but since i'm using JDBC there isn't a quick fix. Any guidance here on a preferred approached would be very appreciated. Potential fixes 1) extra connection config keyword that can replace limit with x (sample in teradata's case) 2) check connection id/name for teradata and then replace limit with sample **Pre Change** **Post Change** **Connection Settings**

I and a few others have been hitting the same error reported by Vijay, going to revert this commit. @jlowin

I'm sorry to hear it -- I am confused, however.

This is a totally fresh Python2 environment:

```
/usr/bin
‚ñ∂ ipython2
Python 2.7.13 |Continuum Analytics, Inc.| (default, Dec 20 2016, 23:05:08)

In [3]: ConfigParser.read_file
Out[3]: <unbound method ConfigParser.read_file>

```

I did have to `pip install configparser` because otherwise it refused to import the module at all -- is it possible your configparsers are out of date? I notice it is not a requirement for Airflow (though I always assumed it was part of the standard library until this test, to be honest)

I don't have too much time to look into this at the moment (focusing on release stuff right now), but my ConfigParser on OSX on python 2.7.12 does not have a read_file. method (and you're right that it's part of the standard library, not sure what that pip package is for).
Interesting -- go for the revert, I'm really sorry to have caused you guys trouble!

That's because [configparser](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/configparser) from PyPI is a backport of the Python3 config parser. The right way to import the vanilla one in Python 2 is `import ConfigParser`. I do not really see the benefit of adding a dependency on another package for this.

1. Handle state of QUEUED, also after restart of Backfill - i.e. like we do with the orphaned tasks of a scheduled dag run
2. Reintroduce some of the earlier executor logic (ie. verify queued/running tasks in the executor)
3. Split up some of the logic to make it easier to test separate parts

I think the two proposed changes (raise error when detecting join on ALL_SUCCESS and two new triggers) sound good, but can be done after 1.8...unless we really squeeze it in since it would be a breaking change.

The only thing I would add regarding the new triggers, is that ALL_SUCCESS_OR_SKIPPED might make more sense as a default when ALL_SUCCESS becomes strictly for successes.

@aoen closing/merging these is going a bit fast imho - tests have not run and the commit message is unclean (just a copy of the PR message). Can we take it a little bit slower?

My bad on the tests, need to unlearn my habit of assuming tests have been run if something is mergeable :). Commit message I cleaned up a bit (e.g. it had [AIRFLOW-XXX] and I removed the reviewers), are there other things that should be changed?

The commit message now reads

```
Please accept this PR that addresses the following
issues:
-
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-937

Testing Done:
- Shouldn't change functionality significantly,
should pass existing tests (if they exist)

This leads to slightly different results, but it
reduced the time of this endpoint from 90s to 9s
on our data, and the existing logic for task_ids
was already incorrect (task_ids may not be
distinct across dags)
```

It doesn't specify why and what, i.e. it is unclear why something is wrong (need to follow link) and what is fixed. `Please accept this PR` doesn't really add value to the message.

I understand the need and want to get fixes in quickly, but being able to go through an understandable history is just as important :).
Makes sense, I'll augment the template to reduce the need to mess around with user commit messages so much.
I normally use the user commit message and ask them / educate them to provide a good one themselves. Makes our lives easier in the end. Do you use the PR message on purpose with the airflow-pr tool?

Please note that if you have in flight scheduled dag runs and you are trying to backfill those with a limited set of tasks then the tasks that are outside of this limited set might stop running. I consider that  and edge case and probably even bad practice until you prove me otherwise ;-).

It happens because of the run_id change to "backfill"

LGTM but that logic is quite complicated, we should simplify it soon...

@aoen @saguziel @mistercrunch 

This is to explain my perspective and to do a suggestion for a fix that is acceptable, considering your comments. 

Assumptions:

1.  Backfills either create DagRuns (ie. to fill in a gap between runs) or update DagRuns (ie. partial rerun or fill in a gap in a run)
2. A Backfill DagRun can consist of a subset of tasks from the "original" DAG (for lack of a better word). Let's call this a `subset dag_run` for simplicity.

Issues to resolve:

1. To create a `subset dag_run` a DAG is created with the same identifier as the original DAG. 
2. The integrity of a DagRun is defined by the cohesion of its tasks
3. The state of the DagRun (=SUCCESS, RUNNING) is determined by the state of the tasks in the DagRun
4. A backfill can override a scheduled run (run_id changes)

Suggested solution:
1. A Backfill will override a scheduled DagRun. As we don't have a proper foreign key relationship between tasks and dag_runs (tasks should be pointing to a unique id, instead of dag_id, execution_date), all tasks in the dag run and "original" dag_run will point to the Backfill dag run. Ie. the run_id of the original dag_run will be overwritten.
2. If a `subset dagrun` creates a new DagRun it will only create the tasks that are part of subset dag.
3. DagRun.verify_integrity will only consider tasks that are part of the DAG that is being run, for a `subset dag` this means a subset of tasks. This means it can only add tasks instances to a `subset dagrun`, as it has no way of determining if certain tasks have been removed. If it is not running a subset, it can consider all tasks and mark them `REMOVED` if needed. => this requires the "original" dag definition to be present or a `partial` flag. `If self.dag.partial == True: do_no_set_removed`.
4. The state of the DagRun will be determined by the set of tasks of that dag that has run last. Ie. in case of a `subset dag` some tasks could have failed in the original dagRun, but the DagRun can be marked successful.

Consequences:
1. In the UI DagRuns can be marked successful, while some tasks have been marked failed. This can be resolved when we have a proper foreign key for tasks -> dag runs, allowing versioning of runs.
2. Overriding an in flight scheduled run by a backfill delivers undetermined results (although we have some protections). Resolved when backfills are in the scheduler
3. In case a scheduled DagRun is overridden by a Backfill, you cannot clear the state again to have the tasks scheduled by the scheduler. This wasn't possible anyway in earlier versions of Airflow and remains a limitation for now - or you would have ended up in No. 2 - undetermined results. Resolved when backfills are part of the scheduler.

Makes sense?

on the tasks that got set to UP_FOR_RETRY 

here's the log from one of the task attempts that got marked UP_FOR_RETRY with your changes, but is now never actually getting retried.

https://gist.github.com/vijaykramesh/16e0ba334d1d5bd7f7a885414ac3fb21

The DAG being tested is basically https://gist.github.com/vijaykramesh/707262c83429ab2a3f5ee701879813e3 but with a lower sleep time (to mimic "processing") in the tasks themselves (even with just 5s I can get the problem to occur) and with depends_on_past = True so I can isolate it to the first dag run running.
in this case it doesn't seem like restarting the scheduler helps either, as the task instance still has a null end_date.
Ah let me fix that, sorry.
@vijaykramesh fixed the issue, tested with your DAG and seems to work now. It now respects the retry_delay as well.

alright, verified locally this works as well (I set retry_delay to something low and the UP_FOR_RETRY tasks got picked up)

Thanks so much, this definitely addresses the problem we were having (currently I have a cron job restarting the scheduler every 30 minutes to deal with it in production)

Well its hard to write a unit test for this scenario (would be more of an integration test really ..)
All issues arise by the way the plugin folder is scanned and imported dynamically

the plugin tests right now just do:
```    def test_executors(self):
        from airflow.executors.test_plugin import PluginExecutor
        assert issubclass(PluginExecutor, BaseExecutor)
```
which tests none of the issues.

To make the test I'd need to point the airflow.cfg to a custom plugin folder inside the testing folder and choose a custom executor, or set these value programatically (needs to be very early in the __init__ cycle). I've only worked with airflow for 1 week so don't have enough experience with its codebase to pull that off cleanly.

If you could provide me with an example how to do the custom plugin folder & executer setting for a unit test I could provide the rest of the actual testing code.

I apologize I do not have the time available atm to fully familiarize myself with the testing code.
